docs.lead_paragraph: Many people probably don’t trust Washington on health care reform because, right now at least, they just don’t trust Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Olympia J. Snowe has broken with Republicans before. Now, Democrats are looking to her on health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: For some, pills like Viagra and Cialis don’t work. And even if they do, there are more cost-effective ways to treat a problem that grows more common with age.

headline.seo: Treatments for Erectile Dysfunction Go Beyond a Pill
headline.main: For Common Male Problem, Hope Beyond a Pill
headline.print_headline: For Common Male Problem, Hope Beyond a Pill

docs.snippet: For some, pills like Viagra and Cialis don’t work. And even if they do, there are more cost-effective ways to treat a problem that grows more common with age.

docs.lead_paragraph: As polls show support for a health care overhaul slipping, advocates for change are trying to win back the public. A new television advertisement that began running Friday in 12 states tries to convince middle-class families who already have health insurance that a change would be good for them. ''Eight ways reform matters to you,'' says the narrator over upbeat music and scenes of patients. ''A cap on deductibles and out-of-pocket costs. No annual or lifetime limits on coverage. Preventive care, covered.'' And so it goes, checking off the eight supposed benefits, before directing viewers to a new Web site, FactsAboutReform.org.
docs.abstract: New TV advertisement that is running in 12 states tries to convince middle-class families who already have health insurance that change would be good for them; spot is second in $12 million series from strange-bedfellows coalition (Families USA, American Medical Assn, Federation of American Hospitals, Service Employees International Union and pharmaceutical industry) that has joined to promote overhaul; photo (M)
docs.snippet: As polls show support for a health care overhaul slipping, advocates for change are trying to win back the public. A new television advertisement that began running Friday in 12 states tries to convince middle-class families who already have health...

docs.lead_paragraph: Which overhaul outcome would be best for the stock market? A recent analysis by Goldman Sachs concludes that a bipartisan compromise in Washington would be good news for investors in health care stocks.
docs.abstract: Goldman Sachs analysis concludes that bipartisan compromise in Washington on health care reform would be good news for investors in health care stocks (S)
docs.snippet: Which overhaul outcome would be best for the stock market?      A recent analysis by Goldman Sachs concludes that a bipartisan compromise in Washington would be good news for investors in health care stocks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Under the House health bill now circulating, many Medicare beneficiaries would pay higher premiums for prescription drug coverage, but many would also see their total drug spending decline, the Congressional Budget Office said Friday. And it would not be only Medicare patients who would spend less, according to the budget office, which said the drug-related provisions of the House bill would save the federal government $30 billion from 2010 to 2019.
docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office says that House health bill would save federal government $30 billion from 2010 to 2019; says many Medicare beneficiaries would pay higher premiums for prescription drug coverage, but many would also see their total drug spending decline (S)
